verses.text: There is punishment for one who is quick to rebuke, but a person who restrains his anger avoids injury.
verses.comment: Patience is recommended over swift anger. The wisdom here echoes other biblical calls to slow anger (James 1:19), advising self-restraint and wisdom in speech and discipline.

verses.text: A silent man is considered wise, and one who keeps his lips closed is thoughtful.
verses.comment: Silence is linked to wisdom throughout the Bible. This connects to Christ’s silence before His accusers (Matthew 27:12-14), demonstrating humility and wisdom in the face of trial.

verses.text: Speaking at the wrong time is like poking a wound; restraint at the right moment brings understanding.
verses.comment: Wisdom is knowing when to speak and when to be silent. The timing of our words matters in loving one another and preserving unity, much as Christ guided His disciples with wise timing.

verses.text: There is one who keeps silent and is thought to be wise, and another is detested for much talking.
verses.comment: Talkativeness is discouraged, aligning with biblical warnings against idleness in speech (Matthew 12:36). This virtue of silent wisdom echoes teachings preserved and valued by the earliest Christian communities.

verses.text: Some people keep quiet because they have nothing to say; others keep silent because they know when to speak.
verses.comment: Discernment is required to know when to speak or remain silent, a concept illustrated in the Wisdom literature and fulfilled in the prudent example set by Jesus Himself.

verses.text: A wise person will wait for the right moment; a braggart and fool miss the proper time.
verses.comment: Patience allows wisdom to be fruitful. The spiritual meaning looks toward waiting upon God’s will as the saints did, trusting in providence rather than self-assertion.

verses.text: Whoever talks a lot offends, and whoever claims authority will be hated.
verses.comment: This reminds us of the responsibility of teachers and leaders (cf. James 3:1-2). There’s a spiritual dimension: true authority flows from humility and service.

verses.text: There may be prosperity through misfortune, and a windfall may turn to loss.
verses.comment: Worldly gain and loss are temporary. The text urges trust in God over material security—a core biblical theme (Matthew 6:19-21).

verses.text: There is a gift that does you no good, and there is a gift whose return pays back double.
verses.comment: True generosity brings blessings—giving with right intention matters (see Luke 6:38). Spiritual and temporal rewards often exceed what is given in faith.

verses.text: Dishonor may be followed by honor, and some are lifted up after being humbled.
verses.comment: Humility precedes true exaltation (Luke 14:11). This is fulfilled in Christ’s own path from humiliation to resurrection glory (Philippians 2:5-11).

verses.text: Others buy much for a small price but pay back seven times more.
verses.comment: Justice and restitution remain a theme. The idea of scales being balanced ultimately is echoed scripturally in the doctrine of God’s perfect justice.

verses.text: The wise person makes himself beloved through his words, but gifts of fools are wasted.
verses.comment: The value of wise, gracious speech is affirmed by both Old and New Testament writers (Ephesians 4:29). Gifts offered without wisdom—such as charity for recognition—have less value.

verses.text: A fool’s gift brings you no advantage, because his eyes are many instead of one.
verses.comment: This quirky image signals the undirected, unwise heart—without singleminded vision, gifts cannot serve God’s glory. The spiritual life requires focus and integrity.

verses.text: He gives little and reproaches much; he opens his mouth like a herald, but today he lends and tomorrow demands repayment.
verses.comment: Charity must reflect God’s grace—giving without expecting in return. The spiritual discipline of almsgiving is at the heart of Christian life and worship.

verses.text: A hateful man’s gift wears out the eyes, and before you know it, it brings only tears and shame.
verses.comment: Cautions us against manipulation disguised as generosity. This aligns with Christ’s teaching to give in secret and not for the praise of others (Matthew 6:1-4).

verses.text: Wisdom locked up in a fool’s mouth is like speech tied up in the mouth of an ignorant person.
verses.comment: Here, true wisdom is inaccessible to the foolish for lack of virtue and humility; spiritual understanding requires openness to God.

verses.text: Better a person who hides his foolishness than one who hides his wisdom.
verses.comment: Discretion with wisdom is valued, but hiding the truth given by God is warned against. Consider Jesus’ teaching that light is not to be hidden under a basket (Matthew 5:15).

verses.text: Unrestrained talk brings only trouble; the tongue of the slanderer can bring about a downfall.
verses.comment: The destructive power of speech reminds us of the biblical importance of guarding the tongue, a principle applied rigorously within the unity of the Church.

verses.text: Do not repeat the words you hear nor disclose any hidden thing, and you will not suffer loss.
verses.comment: Preserving confidence and not spreading gossip is central to love of neighbor (Leviticus 19:16) and building a trustworthy community.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to confess your sins, and do not oppose the current of the river.
verses.comment: This encourages confessing sins openly—a practice confirmed in James 5:16 and among the first believers (John 20:22-23; see also Psalm 32:5). The command highlights God’s mercy made available through sincere repentance.

verses.text: Do not subject yourself to every fool, nor be partial to the powerful.
verses.comment: Stresses the need for integrity and impartiality. In the New Covenant, all are equal before God (Galatians 3:28) and should be treated with justice.

verses.text: Even for the sake of justice, do not be partial to anyone.
verses.comment: God’s justice is impartial. The call to righteousness is affirmed throughout Scripture, especially regarding proper judgment among God’s people.

verses.text: Do not try to conceal your wisdom with foolish words, for wisdom will reveal itself in the words of the wise.
verses.comment: Genuine wisdom overflows in wholesome speech—something seen reflected in Christ, the Word made flesh, whose wisdom dazzled the crowds (Luke 2:47).

verses.text: A rich person’s gift may bring him many enemies, and the gratitude of the wicked is short-lived.
verses.comment: Material gifts fare poorly without righteousness—a reminder of Christ’s teaching on the dangers of wealth not used for good (Mark 10:23-25).

verses.text: Giving a gift from ill-gotten gains is like putting a stone in a sling; it ends up swinging back at the giver.
verses.comment: Wealth gained unjustly brings eventual ruin. This spiritual law underlies Christian teaching on honesty and restitution.

verses.text: The arrogant insult the humble, and the violent threaten those who fear God.
verses.comment: A warning against pride and violence; God exalts the humble and resists the proud. The meek are promised the Kingdom (Matthew 5:5).

verses.text: A borrower’s promise makes him anxious, but to the one who helps his neighbor, there is assurance.
verses.comment: Generosity offers peace, but dependence on debt brings anxiety. Christian tradition emphasizes works of mercy as evidence of authentic faith.

verses.text: If you lose your modesty, what will you have left? If you abandon your soul, who will pity you?
verses.comment: Guarding the soul is paramount, for nothing is worth more than our salvation (Matthew 16:26).

verses.text: Silence is preferable to speaking rashly, and finding a wise listener is better than a boastful speaker.
verses.comment: The virtue of silence and wise company is central. Community and the guidance of wise elders are spiritual safeguards.

verses.text: Words lavishly spoken are rejected, and incessant talk earns only contempt.
verses.comment: Empty talk is discouraged, focusing instead on meaningful, loving communication that builds up the body of Christ.

verses.text: A proverb from a fool’s mouth will be rejected, for he does not say it at the right time.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not merely knowing sayings, but applying them with discernment and virtue. This calls us to spiritual maturity—a hallmark of authentic Christian discipleship.
